questions: What is the grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy?
What is the waiting period for pre-existing diseases (PED) to be covered?
Does this policy cover maternity expenses, and what are the conditions?
What is the waiting period for cataract surgery?
Are the medical expenses for an organ donor covered under this policy?
What is the No Claim Discount (NCD) offered in this policy?
Is there a benefit for preventive health check-ups?
How does the policy define a 'Hospital'?
What is the extent of coverage for AYUSH treatments?
Are there any sub-limits on room rent and ICU charges for Plan A?

answers: A grace period of fifteen days is provided for monthly premium payments, and thirty days for all other payment modes, to renew or continue the policy without losing continuity benefits. Coverage is not available during the grace period unless the premium is paid in installments.

The waiting period for pre-existing diseases (PED) is 36 months of continuous coverage after the inception of the first policy. If the sum insured is enhanced, the exclusion applies afresh to the increased amount.

The policy covers maternity expenses for delivery or lawful medical termination of pregnancy, limited to two instances during the insured's lifetime, under the Diamond and Platinum Plans, provided the plan has been in force for at least 24 months. Expenses must be incurred as in-patients in India.
The waiting period for cataract surgery is 24 months of continuous coverage after the inception of the first policy.

The policy covers in-patient hospitalization medical expenses for an organ donor if the donation conforms to the Transplantation of Human Organs Act 1994, but it does not cover pre-hospitalization, post-hospitalization, screening expenses, or any complications related to organ harvesting.
The No Claim Discount (NCD) under the Family Medicare Policy is 5% for every claim-free year, up to a maximum of 15%.

Preventive health check-ups are beneficial as they cover expenses up to 1% of the average sum insured of the preceding 3 years, with a maximum of Rs. 5,000 per person or Rs. 10,000 per policy period for floater policies, provided the check-up is done at authorized centers.

The policy defines a 'Hospital' as an establishment with qualified nursing staff and medical practitioners available round the clock, at least ten inpatient beds in smaller towns or fifteen in larger areas, a fully equipped operation theatre, and maintains daily patient records.

The policy covers AYUSH treatments for inpatient care under Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Sidha, and Homeopathy systems up to the sum insured limit specified in the policy schedule, provided the treatment is in an AYUSH Hospital.
For Plan A, room rent is limited to 2% of the Sum Insured, up to a maximum of Rs. 5,000 per day, and ICU charges are limited to 5% of the Sum Insured, up to a maximum of Rs. 10,000 per day.

questions: What is the ideal spark plug gap recommended?
Does this come in tubeless tyre version?
Is it compulsory to have a disc brake?

answers: The ideal spark plug gap recommended is 0.8-0.9 mm.
Yes, the vehicle comes with tubeless tyres. The front tyre is 80/100-18 47P and the rear tyre is 90/90-18 51P, both tubeless.
The document does not specify that having a disc brake is compulsory. It mentions both disc and drum brake variants, indicating that disc brakes are not mandatory.

questions: When will my root canal claim of Rs 25,000 be settled?
I have done an IVF for Rs 56,000. Is it covered?
I did a cataract treatment of Rs 100,000. Will you settle the full Rs 100,000?
Give me a list of documents to be uploaded for hospitalization for heart surgery.
I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?

answers: Your root canal claim will be settled within 15 days from the receipt of the last necessary document. If an investigation is required, the settlement will occur within 45 days.

Assisted Reproduction Treatment, including IVF, is covered up to Rs. 2,00,000 after a 36-month waiting period from the policy's inception. Ensure the treatment was initiated after this period to be eligible for coverage.
The policy covers cataract treatment expenses up to 25% of the Sum Insured or INR 40,000 per eye, whichever is lower, per policy period. Therefore, the full Rs 100,000 will not be settled.

For hospitalization for heart surgery, upload the following documents: original bills, receipts, discharge certificate, medical history, prescriptions, diagnostic reports, payment receipts, implant stickers, and any other required documents by the company/TPA.

You can raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with us if the expenses are covered under the policy terms, such as hospitalization costs up to the sum insured and related pre/post-hospitalization expenses. Ensure the expenses align with the policy's coverage limits and conditions.

questions: Is Non-infective Arthritis covered?
Can I put thums up instead of oil
Give me JS code to generate a random number between 1 and 100
I renewed my policy yesterday, and I have been a customer for the last 6 years. Can I raise a claim for Hydrocele?
Is abortion covered?

answers: Non-infective Arthritis is covered but may have a waiting period as specified in the policy.
The document specifies using Hero genuine engine oil or recommended grade oil, SAE 10W 30 SL Grade (JASO MA2), and does not mention using Thums Up or any other substitute.
The document does not provide JavaScript code or information related to generating random numbers.

You can raise a claim for Hydrocele if it is not a pre-existing condition, as pre-existing diseases have a waiting period of 36 months. Since you have been a customer for 6 years, the waiting period for pre-existing conditions would have expired.

Abortion is covered as lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the policy period, except during the first twelve weeks from conception. This benefit is applicable only under the Diamond and Platinum Plans.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?

answers: The document does not provide specific information on the legal classification of a stolen car case. For such legal matters, refer to the Indian Penal Code or consult legal authorities.
According to Article 1 of the Constitution, the official name of India is "India, that is Bharat."

Yes, it is legal to be arrested without a warrant, but the arrested person must be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time, and informed of the grounds for arrest. They also have the right to consult a legal practitioner.
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
No, it is not allowed. The Constitution of India prohibits discrimination in employment on the grounds of caste (Article 16).
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "Untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form, making the enforcement of any disability arising out of "Untouchability" an offense punishable by law.

The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice (social, economic, and political), Liberty (of thought, expression, belief, faith, and worship), Equality (of status and opportunity), and Fraternity (assuring the dignity of the individual and unity and integrity of the Nation).

If the government acquires your land for a project, it is generally lawful if compensation is provided at market value, especially if the land is under personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit. However, specific laws and exceptions may apply, particularly in Scheduled Areas.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Indian Constitution.
No, it is not legal. The Constitution of India prohibits the employment of children below the age of fourteen years in any factory or hazardous employment.

According to the Constitution of India, all citizens have the right to freedom of speech and expression and to assemble peaceably without arms (Article 19). Being stopped from speaking at a protest may infringe on these rights unless restricted by law for reasons such as public order.
According to Article 24, no child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.

The Constitution of India allows religious institutions to manage their own affairs in matters of religion, which may include restricting entry based on gender. However, such practices must align with public order, morality, and health as per Article 25.

The significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution is not detailed in the provided document sections. For specific information on Article 21, please refer to the full text of the Indian Constitution.
The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens.

The government cannot stop you from changing your religion as Article 25 of the Indian Constitution guarantees freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health.
The right being violated is the "Protection of life and personal liberty" under Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).
The document does not provide specific details on the restrictions under Article 19(2) regarding freedom of speech. For precise information, please refer to the full text of the Indian Constitution.

You cannot be denied admission to a public university solely based on being from a backward community, as the Constitution prohibits discrimination on grounds of caste. You may seek legal recourse if denied admission on such grounds.

questions: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
According to Newton, what are the three laws of motion and how do they apply in celestial mechanics?
How does Newton derive Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) from his laws of motion and gravitation?
How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
What mathematical tools did Newton use in Principia that were precursors to calculus, and why didn't he use standard calculus notation?
How does Newton use the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion?
How does Newton handle motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids?
In what way does Newton's notion of absolute space and time differ from relative motion, and how does it support his laws?
Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?
Do we know any other descent of Isaac Newton apart from his grandfather?

answers: Newton defines 'quantity of motion' as the measure arising from the velocity and quantity of matter conjointly, while 'force' is described as a power of resisting, which every body uses to maintain its state of rest or uniform motion.

Newton's three laws of motion are: 1) A body remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by a force, 2) The change in motion is proportional to the applied force, and 3) For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. In celestial mechanics, these laws explain planetary orbits and gravitational forces.

Newton derives Kepler's Second Law by demonstrating that the force retaining a planet in its orbit is always directed towards the sun, leading to the conclusion that areas described by a radius from the sun are proportional to the times, as shown in the document.

Newton demonstrates that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses by showing that the force of gravity towards a planet arises from the forces towards all its parts, each in reciprocal proportion to the square of the distance. He verified this principle through the motions of celestial bodies and Kepler's laws.

Newton argues that gravitational force acts universally on all masses because every particle has a gravitating power, and in spherical masses, this force operates as if confined to their centers, affecting all bodies proportionally to their mass and inversely to the square of the distance.

Newton explains that planetary orbits are perturbed by mutual attractions, with the sun's gravitational force being the primary influence, while the interactions between planets and comets cause minor inequalities in their motions.
Newton used his method of fluxions, a precursor to calculus, in Principia. He preferred the Geometrical Method over algebraic calculations, which is why he didn't use standard calculus notation.

Newton explains orbital motion by stating that centripetal force, which he equates to gravity, retains celestial bodies in their orbits by drawing them towards a central body, such as the sun, and varies inversely with the square of the distance from the center. This force ensures planets move in conic sections, like ellipses, with the sun at one focus.

Newton explains that motion in resisting media like air or fluids is affected by the resistance proportional to the motion excited by the projectile in the fluid, which acts to retard its motion. The resistance is related to the density of the fluid and the velocity of the projectile.

Newton's notion of absolute space and time is independent and unchanging, unlike relative motion, which is based on external references and can vary. This distinction supports his laws by providing a consistent framework for understanding motion and forces, unaffected by relative perceptions.
Isaac Newton's grandfather was Robert Newton.
Beyond his grandfather, Robert Newton, Sir Isaac Newton's descent cannot be traced with certainty. Two family traditions suggest either Scotch extraction or origins from Newton in Lancashire.
